form.definition: noun W is the twenty-third letter of the English alphabet.
abbreviation for west.
abbreviation for Western Australia.
noun A wad of something is a lump of it that has been packed tightly together. He stopped the bleeding with a wad of cottonwool. The old sailor was chewing on a wad of tobacco.
verb If someone waddles, they walk like a duck, taking short steps and swaying from side to side.
verb If you wade through water, you walk through it and it reaches your knees or higher up your body. We waded across the ford.
verb If you wade through something, you get through it slowly and with difficulty. I'm still wading through the consultants' report.
noun A wafer is a thin crisp biscuit.
verb When a dog wags its tail, it shakes it from side to side.

verb In informal language, if you say a student wags school, you mean that they don't go there although they're supposed to. He was in terrible trouble when his parents found out he'd been wagging classes.

noun A wage is the money that someone, especially a labourer or a factory worker, earns in a regular job. Sometimes this word is used in the plural, wages, with the same meaning. He didn't feel he could get married until he was earning a good wage. I have to spend nearly half my wages on rent.
verb In formal language, if you say that a country wages war, you mean that it fights a war.
noun A wager is a bet. He laid a small wager on the Melbourne Cup.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb wager

form.definition: verb If someone wails, they cry loudly and continuously. The woman lay down on her son's grave and wailed. He left me alone with the wailing baby.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wail Daisy let out a loud wail when I told her she couldn't go.

form.definition: noun Your waist is the middle part of your body between your ribs and your hips. This exercise will trim your waist. She wore a green sash around her waist. This dress has a high waist.

verb If you wait, you remain somewhere until something happens. If you can wait five minutes, I'll give you a lift. Don't wait for meI'll catch you up. We can do the repair while you wait, or you can collect it tomorrow.

verb If you are waiting, you are expecting something to happen. I'm still waiting for a reply to my letter. I don't know what the new boss will be likewe'll have to wait and see. I'll be with you in a minutesorry to keep you waiting.
verb If something is waiting, it is ready for you. The store called to say that your curtains are waiting.

verb If you say something can't wait, you mean that it is urgent and must be dealt with immediately. Use our courier service when your deliveries just can't wait. The ironing can waitlet's have dinner now.
noun A wait is an interval before something happens. On our way home from America we had a four-hour wait at Los Angeles airport. I missed the bus and faced a long wait for the next.
verb If someone waits on you in a cafe or restaurant, they ask what you want to order and then bring it to you.

can't wait In informal language, if you say you can't wait to do something, you mean that you are very excited about it and looking forward to doing it. Alf and Joan can't wait to see their daughter's new baby. Christmas is only three weeks awayI can't wait!
noun A waiter is someone whose job is to serve people in a cafe or restaurant. They ask the customers what they want to order and then bring it to them.
verb When you wake or wake up, you stop being asleep. I wake at 5 a.m. and get up at 5.30.
verb If you wake someone or wake them up, you make them stop being asleep. The noise from the builders woke me.

verb When you walk, you move along by putting one foot in front of the other. Sometimes I leave the car at home and walk to work. I really enjoy walking in the bush. He opened the door and walked into the room. Sarah's baby's just learning to walk.
noun If you go for a walk, you walk somewhere for pleasure. Let's go for a walk by the river.
noun Your walk is your gait or the way you walk. I'd recognise Don's walk anywhere.
walk out If you walk out, you leave suddenly because you are offended or angry. She said if they spoke to her like that she'd walk out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun walker A party of walkers are missing in the national park.

form.definition: noun A walkover is an easy victory. Our team won 10-0it was a walkover.
noun A wall is a barrier made of bricks or stone. The thieves had climbed over the back wall. I sat on the garden wall and watched them work.
noun The walls of a building or room are its vertical sides. They were caught painting graffiti on the walls of the school. We knocked down the wall between the lounge and the kitchen.

drive up the wall In informal language, if you say someone drives you up the wall, you mean that they irritate you. They make you feel impatient with them. Hari drives me up the wall with his endless chatter. This stupid computer program is driving me up the wallI just can't make it do what I want.

like talking to a brick wall In informal language, if you say talking to someone is like talking to a brick wall, you mean that it doesn't make any differencethey don't take any notice of what you say, or they don't understand what you mean. Honestly, the number of times I've asked Kate to clear up her thingsit's like talking to a brick wall.

noun A wallet is a flat leather or plastic purse used for paper money and other things such as credit cards. He took $20 out of his wallet and gave it to her. The body was identified from the papers in his wallet.
noun Wallpaper is patterned paper that is glued to the walls of a room as a way of decorating it.
noun A waltz is a piece of music which has a rhythm of three beats to each bar, with the emphasis on the first beat.
noun A waltz is a dance which you can do with a partner in time to this music.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb waltz They waltzed around the room.

form.definition: verb If you wander, you go around casually from place to place. She spent a couple of years wandering around Europe. I enjoy wandering around town on Saturdays. The old lady was found wandering the streets in her nightdress.
verb If your mind wanders, you do not concentrate. You start thinking about other things. I tried to follow the lecture but my mind wandered. He's over eighty now and sometimes his mind wanders.
verb When the moon wanes, it gets smaller each night in the period after the full moon.
verb When something wanes it becomes less in amount or intensity. By now my enthusiasm for the project was waning. Membership of the organisation has waned in recent years.

verb In informal language, if you say someone wangles something, you mean that they manage to get what they want, often by cunning. 'How did you wangle the car for the day?' 'I said I needed it for work.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wangle That's a good wangle to get time off work.

form.definition: verb Wank is an informal word for masturbate.

noun In informal language, if you say that someone's behaviour is a wank, you mean they have done something ridiculous or insincere just for their own pleasure. All her talk about discovering her real self is a total wank.

verb If you want something, you desire it. You wish to possess it or for it to happen. Note that it is often more polite to say would like instead of want. Do you want anything from the shops? Tina wants a bicycle for her birthday. I want to go overseas next year. I've done my bestwhat more do you want? I don't want to talk about it.
verb If you say something wants some treatment, you mean that it needs to have it. The car wants a good cleanit's a disgrace.
noun War is fighting, usually on a large scale and over a long period of time. The peace talks failed and war broke out again. My father served in the Korean War.
noun A war can also be a strong campaign against something. These policies seem to be winning the war against inflation. The police have declared war on drink driving.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See warfare.

form.definition: noun In a hospital, a ward is a room with several beds in it, where patients stay while they are treated. ...the children's ward. ...the maternity ward.
noun A ward is one of the areas that a district or town is divided into for elections. We have to vote for two councillors out of the six candidates for our ward.

noun A ward is a child who is in the care of a guardian or of the state because their parents are dead or not able to look after them properly. He made Julia his ward, and paid for her education. When their marriage broke up, the youngest three children became wards.

ward off If you ward something off, you manage to keep it away from you or prevent it from happening. He warded off the dog with his umbrella. I think I'm getting a cold, but I'm taking vitamins to ward it off. We hope that these new businesses will ward off the threat of retrenchments.

noun The warden of a building is the person who is in charge of security and maintenance in it. I locked myself out of my room and had to get the warden to let me in. If there are problems with the plumbing, let the warden know. I called and left a message with the warden.
noun A warder is a prison officer.

noun A wardrobe is a cupboard for storing clothes which you keep on hangers, such as suits, shirts and skirts. Often wardrobes also have shelves or drawers in them. We fastened the wardrobe to the roof of the car when we moved. My new unit has a built-in wardrobe.
noun Your wardrobe consists of all the clothes that you have. I need to replace part of my winter wardrobe.
noun A warehouse is a large building which is used for storing goods.
noun Warfare is the means and techniques of fighting wars. The museum has a section on warfare through the ages. Chemical weapons are one of the most horrifying aspects of modern warfare.

adjective If something is warm, it is fairly hot. HAND WASH IN WARM WATER It's a warm spring day. The sea is quite warm already. They brought us warm rolls and butter. The paper is still warm from the photocopier.

adjective If you are warm, you feel comfortable because you are not too cold. Are you warm enough, or would you like the fire on? You're not going to be very warm in that flimsy dress. It's important to keep warm when you've got a cold.
adjective If clothes are warm, they keep you from feeling cold because they are thick and cover your body. Bring warm clothesit's snowing in the mountains. This blanket's too warm for the summer.
adjective If you say that someone is warm, you mean that they are friendly and kind. Jane's very warm and welcoming, unlike her husband. He gave me a warm smile.
verb If you warm something, you heat it gently. I turned on the electric blanket to warm the bed. Come in and warm yourself by the fire.
warm to If you warm to someone, you find that you like them. I didn't exactly warm to Elsie when I first met her. He was very quiet, but as I got to know him I gradually warmed to him.

warm up (a) If you warm food up, you heat it so that it is ready to eat. Usually it has already been cooked. There's soup for lunchI just have to warm it up. I'll put the leftovers in the fridgewe can warm them up tomorrow. Will you eat the quiche cold or shall I warm it up?
(b) In sport, if you warm up before a race or match, you prepare for it by doing exercises just before it starts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb warmly She smiled warmly and said hello.noun warmth

form.definition: verb If you warn someone, you tell them about possible problems or dangers. He warned us that the road might be flooded. It's not an easy taskdon't say I didn't warn you. You'll be in big trouble if you stuff it up, let me warn you!

verb If you warn someone not to do something, you advise them not to do it or order them not to do it. A $130 fineI warned you not to break the speed limit! She warned the children not to speak to strangers. He warned me not to touch anything on his desk while he was away.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See warning.

form.definition: noun A warning tells people, in spoken words or in writing, that a dangerous or unpleasant thing might happen. The weather bureau has issued a warning that a cyclone is approaching. Lionel ignored my warnings and set off. WARNING: NOT TO BE TAKEN
verb If something warps, it loses its shape and becomes bent or curved. Your tennis racquet will warp if you leave it outside.

dictionary.entry: warpedw@:pt adjective If you say someone is warped, you mean that they have a bitter, distorted view of life. These sick jokes appealed to her warped sense of humour.

form.definition: noun A warrant is an official document which authorises the police to do something, such as search a house or make an arrest. A police officer who comes onto your property or searches your possessions without a warrant and against your wishes may be guilty of trespass.

verb In formal language, if you say something warrants a certain course of action, you mean it makes it necessary or appropriate. The doctors feel that young Ari's symptoms warrant further investigation. His minor breach of etiquette didn't warrant the torrent of abuse he received.

dictionary.entry: warranty`wOr@nti:warranties noun A warranty on a product is a legal recognition of liability. There is a twelve-month warranty on all our appliances.

form.definition: noun A wart is a small raised lump, caused by a virus, which can appear on your skin.

verb If you are wary about something, you are very cautious in the way that you approach it. I'm a bit wary about Jim's tips on the raceslast time I lost $500. I'm wary of getting too involved in her problems. I'd be wary if I were youthe deal seems too good to be true.
verb Was is the first and third person singular form of the past tense of be.

verb When you wash something, you clean it with detergent and water. I've just washed my hair. Wash your hands before dinner. The dye ran when I washed my T-shirt. He paid the boys to wash the car. You should wash the wall before you paint it.
verb When you wash, you wash your body. Just give me half an hour to wash and change, and I'll be ready. You need to wash more frequently in the hot weather.
verb If something is washed somewhere, it is carried there by water. During the storm a lot of soil was washed onto the path. I washed the spider down the plughole.
in the wash If a garment is in the wash, it is waiting to be washed or it has just been washed but is not ready to be worn again. Where's my blue shirt? It must be in the wash.
5 wash out (a) If you wash out a stain, you remove it by washing. I managed to wash out the grease on the collar.
(b) If an event is washed out, it is cancelled because of rain. The match was washed out for the second week running.
wash up When you wash up, you wash the dirty dishes and crockery. I'll cook and you can wash up.

wash your hands of If you say you wash your hands of something, you mean that you accept no further responsibility for it. I've given them my advice, but they won't listenI wash my hands of the whole project. He's your sonyou can't just wash your hands of him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wash These curtains need a wash.adjective washable Is this blouse washable silk, or does it need to be dry-cleaned?noun washing I hung the washing out to dry. I put my shirt in with the dirty washing.

form.definition: adjective If someone is washed-out, they have very little energy because they are tired or ill. We were all washed-out after staying up all night.
noun A washer is a flat plastic or metal ring which is used to keep a bolt or a joint tight. The tap keeps drippingI expect the washer needs to be replaced.
noun A washer is a small piece of cloth which you use to clean your face or body. I bought a set of matching bath towels, hand towels and washers.

verb If you waste something, you use it up carelessly. You use more of it than you need or you use it when you don't really need to. Don't waste water by leaving the tap running. They wasted their money on trashy souvenirs. We've wasted too much time already.

verb If you waste something, you don't take advantage of it. He might have got the job if he'd tried harder, but he wasted the opportunity. Don't waste the sunshine by staying indoors on a day like this!

verb If you say something is wasted on someone, you mean that they don't appreciate or understand it. Don't waste the good wine on Joehe doesn't know the difference. The irony was wasted on her, as she didn't know what he was talking about.
noun Waste is refuse or material that is not wanted. We try to recycle as much of our waste as possible. They discovered rusting cans of toxic waste on the site.
go to waste If something goes to waste, it is not used. Take the cakes home with you or they'll go to waste.
waste away If someone wastes away, they get thinner and thinner. Once he got sick he wasted away before our eyes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun waste It's a waste of time arguing. I was shocked at the waste of resources.adjective waste ...a waste product. I threw out a huge pile of waste paper when I moved office.adjective wasteful Don't be so wasteful with the detergent.

form.definition: noun A wastepaper basket is a container for dry rubbish such as waste paper that is usually kept on the floor next to a desk.

verb If you watch something, you look at it with a lot of attention for some time. The kids are watching television as usual. We watched the parade go past. Watch how I fold the sheets. John's playing football on Saturday and we're all going along to watch.

verb If you watch someone or something, you keep a careful eye on them. Could you watch Laura while I go to the shops? Police watched the suspect for weeks before they arrested him. We are aware of the situation and are watching developments.

verb If you tell someone to watch what they do, you are warning them to be careful. Watch how you handle that knifeit's very sharp. Watch you don't stay too late and miss the last bus. You need to watch your step on the slippery floor.
noun A watch is a small clock which you wear on your wrist. My watch has stopped. What time does your watch say? He looked impatiently at his watch.
keep watch If someone keeps watch over something, they guard it. Two of the soldiers slept while the third kept watch. The dog kept watch over his body until the rescuers arrived.
watch out If you tell someone to watch out, you are warning them to be careful. Watch outthere's a sharp bend coming up! Watch outyou nearly hit me with that thing!

watch out for If you watch out for something, you remain alert in case you see it. In this area you have to watch out for snakes. Watch out for Sammyhe should be arriving any minute now. I've been watching out for a blue pleated skirt for a while.
noun Water is the colourless clear liquid of rain, rivers, lakes and seas. I drank two glasses of water straight down. Cook the pasta in boiling water for ten minutes.
verb If you water a garden, you pour water on it to help the plants grow.

in hot water In informal language, if you say someone is in hot water, you mean that they are in trouble because someone in authority is displeased with them. If you're late again you'll be in hot water!
spend money like water If you say someone spends money like water, you mean that they spend it very freely indeed. He spent money like water after he won the lottery, and soon it was all gone.
water down (a) If you water something down, you make it weaker by adding water to it. The weed killer needs to be watered down before you spray the garden.
(b) If you water something down, you make it weaker. The proposed legislation has been severely watered down during its passage through parliament.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective watery This soup is rather watery.

form.definition: noun Watercolours are paints that artists use which are thinned with water rather than oil. I bought Tommy a box of watercolours for his birthday.
noun A watercolour is a painting done using these paints. On the wall was a watercolour of a street scene.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this word is watercolor.

form.definition: noun A waterfront is the land next to an area of water such as the ocean or a lake. Their holiday house is right on the waterfront.
noun The waterfront is also the wharves in a port. There's been a lot of unrest on the waterfront.
adjective If something is waterlogged, it is completely soaked with water and can't absorb any more. My shoes were waterlogged from walking in the rain.
adjective If something is waterproof, it doesn't let water or other liquids pass through it. The tablecloth has a waterproof backing. Take a waterproof coat in case it rains.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun waterproof You can borrow my waterproof.

form.definition: verb If you waterski, you ski on water. You are towed along at high speed by a motor boat while you stand upright on skis on the surface of the water.
adjective If something is watertight, it doesn't let in any water at all. The join is sealed with rubber to make it watertight.
adjective If something such as a contract or a case against someone is watertight, there is no possibility of arguing about it.
noun The watt is the unit in which electrical power is measured. I bought a 100-watt light globe.
noun A wattle is a small tree that has small, ball-shaped yellow flowers. It's very common in Australia.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is acacia.

form.definition: verb When you wave, you move your hand in the air in order to greet someone or attract their attention. When Ruth saw us she waved. He waved down a taxi.

verb If you wave something, you hold it so that it can be clearly seen, and move it up and down or from side to side in the air. The children waved their flags as they watched the parade. He rushed excitedly into the room waving the announcement. Be careful with that knifedon't wave it around like that.
noun A wave is a surge of water on the surface of the sea caused by winds or the tide. The waves were too high to go fishing.
noun A wave is also a vibration which travels through air or water, such as a sound wave.

noun A wave is a sudden surge of something. The recession produced a wave of bankruptcies. Politicians of all parties are concerned about the crime wave in the area. I felt a wave of anger sweep over me.[qr
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wavy (wavier, waviest) She drew a wavy line. His hair is naturally wavy.

form.definition: noun Wax is a greasy solid substance. The wax from the candle had dripped over the table. You should clean your ears properly to get rid of the wax.
verb If you wax something, you treat it with wax. Be careful on the floorit's just been waxed. He spends ages waxing and polishing his car. The cloth is waxed to make it waterproof.
verb When the moon waxes, it gets bigger each night in the period before the full moon.

noun The way to a place is the route you must take to get there. This street is the way to the beach. We stopped to ask the way. It's easy to lose your way in the bush. I visited Mary on my way home from school.
noun A way is also a particular direction. Which way do we go, right or left? She found herself driving the wrong way down the street. The picture had been hung the wrong way up.
noun A way is also the distance between things. The airport's a long way from the town. A short way further on we came to a river.
noun A way of doing something is the means by which you do it. There are several ways of solving the problem. Don't shout at himyou'll never persuade him that way.
noun A way of doing something can also refer to a particular style in which it is done. He showed me a new way of serving potatoes. I like the way you've done your hair.
noun The way you do something is the manner in which you do it. She looked at me in a strange way.
noun The way something looks or the way you feel is how it looks or how you feel. I can't help the way I feel about Minh. 'So Paul's not coming?' 'It looks that way.'
noun If you talk about the way something happens, often you mean the fact that it happens. I don't like the way she's always complaining.
noun The ways of a person or group are their customs or habits. She has some strange ways, but she's a nice person. I really enjoyed travelling and learning about foreign ways.

by the way You use by the way when you want to remark casually about something. By the way, did you know that Mike and Judy have split up? We really enjoyed the eveningand thank you for the lift, by the way.
give way If you give way to another vehicle when you are driving, you wait and let it go first. Traffic entering the roundabout must give way to cars already in it.
in the way If something is in the way, it is preventing you from moving or from seeing clearly. I want to go out but your car's in the way.
under way If something is under way, it has begun. It is in progress. Work is under way to redevelop the site as a park. The party was well under way by the time we arrived.
adjective If something is way-out, it is very unusual or eccentric. Helen's parents didn't like her way-out clothes.

pronoun You use we to refer to yourself and at least one other person. It can include the person you are talking to, but not necessarily. We all enjoyed the movie. We don't want to inconvenience you. Why don't we go by bus?
form.note: ... NOTE the form us is used when it is the object of a verb or after a preposition.

form.definition: adjective If someone is weak, they can't do things that require a lot of effort. Emil is still weak after his operation.
adjective If something is weak, it is likely to break or fall down under pressure. The supports are too weak to hold much weight.
adjective If someone is weak, they do not have much character. They are easily influenced by other people. These swindlers prey upon people who are weak.
adjective If something such as an argument is weak, it is not convincing. It lacks force and logic. That's the weakest excuse I've ever heard.
adjective If something such as a drink is weak, it has been heavily diluted with water. I can't drink this coffeeit's too weak. She takes her tea very weak, with a slice of lemon.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is strong. ... WORD FAMILY verb weaken After 10 k I began to weaken. She weakened and eventually gave in.noun weakling I used to be a complete weakling until I started working out at the gym.noun weakness The disease causes muscular weakness. They took advantage of her weakness.

form.definition: noun Your wealth is all the money, shares, property and valuables that you own. He is a man of considerable wealth. She left her wealth to charity.

noun A wealth is a large amount of something that is regarded as valuable. He has a wealth of experience in the mining industry. I discovered a wealth of information on the topic at the public library.
adjective If someone is wealthy, they are rich. She comes from a wealthy family.
noun A weapon is an object such as a gun or knife that can be used to kill or injure someone.
verb When you wear a garment, you have it on your body. He was wearing a blue shirt. She wears lots of make-up. I didn't know what to wear to the wedding. You should always wear a hat in the sun.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone wears a certain look on their face, you mean that they have that expression. Her face wore a surprised look. He advanced towards us wearing a grin.
verb The way something wears is how long it lasts before it becomes too damaged to use any more. These shoes have worn well.

noun Wear is clothing of a particular type. This is rather a formal word, used particularly in shops. He sells sports wear. Casual wear will be quite appropriate for the party. There is no sales tax on work wear.
wear away If one thing wears away another, it gradually removes parts of it by moving or rubbing against it. Water has worn away the rock.
wear down If you wear someone down, you keep trying to persuade them so persistently that eventually they give in. Their constant re-submission of the proposal wore us down.

wear out (a) If you wear something out, or if it wears out, you use it so much that it becomes damaged. He made us take our shoes off so as not to wear out the carpet. You'll wear out the clutch by driving like that.
(b) If you wear someone out, you totally exhaust them. Looking after the kids all day has worn me out.
the worse for wear In informal language, if you say that someone looks the worse for wear, you mean that they look rather tired or sick. Sometimes you mean that they are drunk or have a hangover.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See worn.adjective See worn-out.

form.definition: adjective If you are weary of something, you are bored or fed up with it. I'm getting weary of repeating myself: no, you may not borrow my car! I'm weary of the same old routine every day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun weariness I felt a deep weariness creep over me.verb weary (wearies, wearied, wearying) The effort soon wearied him.

form.definition: noun The weather is the state of the atmosphere, such as whether it is hot, cold, windy, raining or snowing. Let's go swimming if the weather's good.

verb If something weathers, it changes as a result of being out in the open and exposed to all sorts of weather conditions. The rocks have weathered into curious shapes. The colour of the roof became mellower as it weathered.

verb If you weather a difficult period in your life, you manage to get through it and continue on normally afterwards. In the last couple of years she's weathered divorce and the death of both her parents.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective weather Did you catch the weather forecast for today?

form.definition: verb When someone weaves cloth, they make it by crossing threads over and under each other on a machine called a loom.
verb If you weave something, you wind it in and out. She wove her hair into a plait.[qr

dictionary.entry:
webwEb
noun A web is the fine, sticky net that spiders spin to trap insects.

form.definition: adjective Webbed feet have the toes joined by a piece of skin. Animals such as platypuses and ducks have webbed feet.
noun A wedding is the ceremony that is held when two people get married. It was just a small wedding with a dozen or so guests.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wedding ...a wedding dress. ...a wedding ring.[qr

dictionary.entry:
wedgewEdZ
noun A wedge is a piece of wood, rubber or metal which is thin at one end and thicker at the other. I put a wedge under the door to hold it open. They split the wood by using wedges.
verb If you wedge something somewhere, you pack it in very tightly. I wedged the last of the boxes into the boot of the car. We all sat wedged together like sardines.
... WORD FAMILY verb wedge I wedged the door open.

form.definition: noun Wednesday is one of the seven days of the week. It comes after Tuesday and before Thursday.
noun A weed is a wild plant that grows by itself where it is not wanted. Henry mowed the lawn and pulled out the weeds.
weed out If you weed things out, you go through them and discard the ones that are not wanted. It's time I weeded out these old files.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb weed We set about weeding the garden.

form.definition: noun A week is seven days in a row, often counted from Monday to Sunday. It takes about a week to get a reply. We get four weeks leave every year. I'm very busy this weekcould we meet next week instead?
noun A weekday is any day from Monday to Friday. We are open from nine to five on weekdays and nine to twelve on Saturdays.
noun The weekend is Saturday and Sunday. What did you do on the weekend? I'm going to visit my parents next weekend. We go to the beach most weekends.
adverb If something happens weekly, it happens every week. Brendan trains for soccer twice weekly.
noun A weekly is a newspaper or magazine which is published once a week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective weekly He goes to a weekly training session.

form.definition: verb If you weep, you cry. Tears fall from your eyes. She sat in the corner weeping softly. We went to the movies and wept buckets at the sad bits.
verb If you weigh something, you measure how heavy it is with a scale or balance.
verb If something or someone weighs a particular amount, that is how heavy it is. Helen weighs fifty five kilos.
weigh into If you weigh into someone, you attack them verbally or physically. He said something she didn't like and she really weighed into him.
weigh on If something weighs on you, it worries you a lot. Her unhappiness has been weighing on me.
weigh your words If you weigh your words, you think very carefully before you speak.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See weight.

form.definition: noun The weight of something is how heavy it is. The fattest of the cats reached 15 kilos in weight. The bridge collapsed under the weight of the truck. I've been putting on weight recently.
noun A weight is a heavy object that is used for some purpose. We need a weight to hold it down until the glue dries. He trains with weights at the gym.

adjective If something is weird, it is very strange or peculiar. His eyes were staring and he looked weird. By a weird coincidence we arrived at exactly the same moment. Their unit is decorated in some very weird colours.
interjection You say welcome to someone to let them know that you are pleased that they have arrived somewhere. Welcome to Australia! Welcome to our new home!

verb If you welcome someone somewhere, you meet them when they arrive and say how pleased you are to see them. We all went to the airport to welcome Andrew back. There will be a reception to welcome our visitors this evening.
verb If you welcome something, you express your pleasure that it has happened. The opposition welcomed the announcement, but said that the measures did not go far enough.

noun A welcome is the way that someone is greeted when they arrive somewhere. They gave us a wonderful welcome and made us feel really at home. The minister did not receive a warm welcome from the strikers.
adjective If someone is welcome, you are pleased to see them. Michael's always a welcome visitor at our place. Come againyou know you're welcome any time.
adjective If something is welcome, you are glad to get it. At last it was time for a welcome rest. A cup of tea would be most welcome.
adjective If you tell someone that they are welcome to do something, you mean that you don't mind at all if they do it. You're welcome to take your shoes off and relax.
you're welcome You can say you're welcome when someone thanks you for something, although often it isn't necessary to say anything.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb welcome They welcomed us.

form.definition: verb If you weld two pieces of metal, you join them together by applying intense heat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun weld The hull had cracked along one of the welds.noun welder He served an apprenticeship as a welder.

form.definition: noun Someone's welfare is how they are doing in lifetheir health, happiness and economic circumstances. I'm not doing this for my sakeit's your welfare I'm interested in.
noun If someone receives welfare, they are paid by the government while they are unemployed or sick.

dictionary.entry:
wellwEl (comparative and superlative forms better, best
adverb Well means 'to a high standard'. Both teams played well. Cristina did very well in her exams.
adverb Well means 'fully' or 'thoroughly'. Be sure and wrap up the parcel well. How well do you know Luigi? You have to push the cartridge well in, until it locks.
adverb Well means 'properly' or 'clearly'. I well remember the day she arrived. I can't see very well without my glasses. Can you hear well enough, or shall I turn up the sound?
adverb Well is also used for emphasis, meaning 'by far'. I got home well before 6 p.m. This falls well outside our responsibilities. He received well over 200 replies. We well underestimated the strength of opposition.
adjective If you are well, you are in good health. Mother hasn't been well lately. 'How are you?' 'I'm very well, thank you.' He's not a well man.
interjection People often say well to introduce a statement or to mark a slight change of subject. Well, I suppose I'd better be going. Well, what do you think? Well, OK, if you're sure it's no trouble. Well, let's not argue about it.
interjection You can also say well, or more emphatically well, well, to show that you are surprised or amused about something. Well, look who's here! Well, you've certainly changed your attitude! Well, well, it just shows you never can tell.
noun A well is a hole in the ground from which you get water. They dug wells to irrigate the land.
noun A well can also be an oil well, from which you get petroleum.
as well As well means 'too' or 'in addition'. As well as means 'in addition to'. I bought some plates, and a bowl as well. Would you like some water as well as the wine?
just as well If you say something is just as well, you mean that it's fortunate that it happened the way it did. It's just as well you didn't go to Balithere's been a cyclone there.

form.definition: noun Your wellbeing is your health and happiness. He's always concerned for the wellbeing of otherssometimes he neglects himself. I felt a tremendous sense of wellbeing after the relaxation session.
adjective If someone is well-off, they have got enough money to live comfortably. Her family is well-off, but they're not rich.
adjective If you are well-off for something, you have got as much of it as you need. I'm fairly well-off for summer clothes, but I need to buy a couple of winter woollies.
verb Went is the past tense of go.
verb Wept is the past tense and past participle of weep.
verb Were is the second person singular form and the plural form of the past tense of be.
contraction of were not. It is used most often in spoken language.
noun If you are facing north, west is on your left. The sun sets in the west.
noun The west of a country or area is the part of it which is towards the west.
the West The West refers to the developed countries with capitalist economies, such as the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See western.adjective west We live on the west side of town. ...West Wyalong.adverb west We drove west. The house faces west.adjective westerly There was a strong westerly wind.

form.definition: adjective Western means in the west. We drove out to the western plains. ...Western Australia.
noun A western is a novel or movie about life in the west of America during the second half of the 19th century when it was being settled by pioneers.
adjective If something is wet, it is soaked or covered with water or some other liquid. I went out without my umbrella and got wet through. Be careful you don't slipthe floor's wet.
adjective When something such as paint or clay is wet, it has not dried out yet. Don't touch the wallsthe paint's still wet. She wrote her name in the wet cement.
adjective When it is wet, it is raining. It's been wet all day. This has been the wettest September for ten years.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is dry.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say someone is wet, you mean that they are feeble and boring. They are not lively or adventurous. Don't be wetit's worth taking a chance.
verb If you wet something, you make it wet. Wet your hair thoroughly, then apply the shampoo.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wet Don't stand outside in the wetcome in and get dry.noun wetness There's still a patch of wetness where I sponged the stain off.

form.definition: noun A whack is a sharp blow or slap. She gave the door an impatient whack with her walking stick.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb whack The ball whacked into the fence. He whacked the cockroach with a book.

form.definition: noun A wharf is a structure built along the edge of a river or a harbour, or projecting into the water. It is used for loading and unloading ships.
pronoun You use what in questions when you want to know something. What's the name of this street? I want to know what you've done.
interjection If you say what? to someone, you invite them to speak or to repeat what they said. 'Joan!' 'What?' 'There's a phone call for you.'
pronoun You can use what before a noun phrase for emphasis. It's raining on your day offwhat rotten luck!
what's what If you say someone knows what's what, you mean that they know how things really are. Ask Catherine. She knows what's what.
pronoun Whatever means 'anything that'. Mum said I could buy whatever I wanted for my birthday.
adjective Whatever means 'no matter what'. Whatever excuse you use, you won't be forgiven.
adverb Whatever is used for emphasis after noun phrases in negative statements with the same meaning as 'at all'. The battery must be flat, there's no power whatever.
pronoun You use whatever after a word or phrase when you don't understand it properly. He said he was an associate member or whatever that means.
adverb Whatsoever is used for emphasis after nouns or noun phrases in negative statements. There's no sense whatsoever in taking a risk.
noun Wheat is a grain used to make flour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wheat ...the wheat crop. ...the wheat harvest.

form.definition: noun Wheels are round objects which turn on an axle and allow vehicles and other things to move along. The back wheels of the car were hanging over the cliff. One of the wheels of the trolley had got stuck in the grating.
noun A wheel can also be a steering wheel. It was a long trip, so we agreed to take turns at the wheel. Don't hold the wheel so tightly.
verb If you wheel something, you push it along on wheels. He had to wheel his bike up the steep hill. They wheeled in the exhibit on a special stand.

verb If you wheel in a certain direction, you turn that way. She must have heard what I said, because she wheeled round and glared at me. I wheeled left and found myself back by the creek. ... WORD FAMILY adjective wheeled The photocopier is mounted on a wheeled base.[qr

dictionary.entry:
wheelbarrow`wi:lbAr@U
noun A wheelbarrow is a small cart you can use to move heavy things, such as bricks or a load of soil or sand. It has one large wheel at the front and two legs at the back. To move it, you lift up the back by two handles and push it along.

form.definition: noun A wheelchair is a chair with two large wheels which is used by people who can't walk.
adverb When means 'at what time'. When does the movie start? He doesn't seem to know when the holidays begin.
conjunction When means 'at the time that'. He filled in the form when he was in the bank.
conjunction When can also mean 'whenever'. She gets flustered when you ask her a question.
conjunction When is also used to mean 'although'. You like to make things seem hard when really they're easy.
conjunction Whenever is used to mean 'at any time'. You can ring me whenever you like.
conjunction Whenever also means 'at every time'. Whenever I call, she's always sick.
adverb You use where to ask about a place. Where are my car keys? Where is she going?
conjunction You use where to refer to the place in which something happens or is. Who knows where the scissors are? I can't remember where I put my sunglasses.
pronoun Where can also mean 'the place in which'. This is where I found the purse.
noun Someone's whereabouts is where they are. I'm not sure of Sam's whereaboutsI think he's gone into town. Please keep us informed of your whereabouts, in case we need to contact you.
conjunction You use whereas to introduce a contrast. This is rather a formal word. Toby is tall, whereas his brother Dan is short.
conjunction Wherever means 'no matter where'. I ring my parents once a week, wherever I am.
adverb In informal language, you use wherever in questions to mean 'where', especially to show surprise, or for emphasis. Wherever did you spring from?
conjunction Whether means 'if' in indirect questions. He asked whether I'd ever been overseas. I was wondering whether you'd like to come to dinner next week.
conjunction You use whether to talk about two or more possible choices. I can't decide whether to buy new shoes or have the old ones repaired.
determiner You use which in questions when there are two or more alternatives. Which train will we catch, the 4 p.m. or the next one?
pronoun Which refers to one amongst a number of things. Which do you like? She knows which she wants.
pronoun Which also means 'that'. It introduces more information about the subject. The book which I borrowed from the library is about war.whichever
pronoun Whichever can refer to any of a number of things. There's a choice of chicken, steak or fish, whichever you like.
determiner Whichever means 'no matter which'. The country's in a mess whichever party wins.
noun A whiff is a slight smell. There was a whiff of cooking coming from the kitchen. Can you smell a whiff of gas?

conjunction If one thing happens while something else does, they both happen at the same time. I went shopping while the car was being fixed. Will you listen while I rehearse my speech? She arrived while I was still in the shower. Buy some now while they're on special.
conjunction You can also use while to introduce a contrast. While he has a point, he's not completely in the right. Jane is tall, while her sister is quite short.

noun A whim is a sudden desire, without a good reason for it. I felt a whim to go for a drive. She went to the party on a whim, and met her future husband there. I can't be bothered catering to all his whims.
verb If an animal or a person whimpers, they make soft cries because they are in pain or distress. The lost boy was whimpering for his mother.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whimper The sick dog gave a whimper as we moved it.

form.definition: verb When a child whines, they complain in an irritating high-pitched voice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whine He let out a whine when I took the toy away from him.

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say someone whinges, you mean that they complain about something unjustly or uselessly. Stop whingeing and get on with it. What's she whingeing about this time?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whinge She wanted to have a whinge about her job, but I hadn't got time to listen. noun whinger.

form.definition: noun A whip is a long strip of leather or rope attached to a handle. You use it to make animals go where you want or to flog people as a punishment.
noun A whip is also an official who helps to run the business of parliament.
verb If someone whips an animal or a person, they strike them with a whip.
verb If you whip cream or egg whites, you stir them very fast so that air gets mixed into them and they become thick and frothy.

whip out If you whip something out, you get it out quickly or unexpectedly. Suddenly the robber whipped out a gun. 6 whip up If you whip up an emotion in someone, you deliberately encourage and increase it. His speeches are calculated to whip up resentment and anger in the audience.
verb If something whirls, it turns or spins around rapidly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whirl I've been so busy my head's in a whirl.

form.definition: noun A whirlwind is a strong violent wind which blows round and round and causes a lot of damage to things in its way.
verb If something whirrs, it makes a quiet buzzing sound typical of a piece of machinery. You could hear the fan whirring overhead.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whirr I soon got used to the whirr of the air conditioner.[qr

form.definition: verb If you whisk eggs, you stir them briskly so that the yolk and the white are well mixed together.

noun A whisk is a kitchen utensil which you use to whisk food. Some types are stirred round and round in the bowl by hand; some have a handle which you turn; and food processors usually have a whisk attachment as well.
verb If you whisk somewhere, you go there quickly and suddenly, without stopping. She whisked past me without a word. The minister's minders whisked him through the crowd.
noun The whiskers of an animal such as a cat are the long stiff hairs that grow near its mouth.
noun Whisky is a strong alcoholic drink made from grain such as barley or rye.

verb When you whisper, you speak very quietly, usually because you don't want someone else to hear what you're saying. We were whispering so as not to wake the children. He whispered to me to come outside.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun whisper She spoke in a whisper.[qr

dictionary.entry:
whistle`wIsl
verb If you whistle, you make a high-pitched noise by pushing your breath through your lips when they are nearly closed. What's that tune you're whistling? He whistled in surprise. He threw stones up at the window and whistled.
verb If something whistles, it makes a high-pitched sound. Could you turn the stove off when the kettle whistles? We could hear the wind whistling all night.
noun A whistle is a small pipe which makes a high-pitched sound when you blow through it. The referee blew his whistle to stop the game. There is a whistle attached to the life jacket to attract the attention of rescuers.
noun A whistle is the sound that you make with your lips almost closed or when you blow on a whistle. You must stop as soon as you hear the whistle. He gave a whistle of appreciation.

form.definition: adjective If something is white, it is the colour of pure snow. It is the lightest colour there is. ...a white car.
adjective Some things are called white if they are light-coloured or pale. ...white wine. I like the white meat of the chicken best.
adjective A white person has pale skin like a European.
adjective If someone goes white, they become very pale, usually because of strong emotion. She went white when she heard the news. He was white with anger. He looked white and drawn after his ordeal.
noun The white of an egg is the transparent part around the yolk.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is eggwhite.

form.definition: white lie If you tell a white lie, you say something that is not true in order to avoid upsetting someone. When Jo asked me what I thought of her new dress I had to tell a white lie.
noun A white ant is an insect which eats wood.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is termite.

dictionary.entry: white-ant`wa:It Ant verb In informal language, if you white-ant something such as an organisation, you undermine it.
white-out`wa:Ita:Ut noun White-out is a white liquid used to paint over a mistake in writing or typing.

form.definition: noun Whitewash is a mixture of lime, chalk and water which you can use to paint walls and ceilings.

verb If someone whitewashes an event or situation, they try to conceal the truth about it and make things seem better than they really are. The principal tried to whitewash the school's poor examination results.
verb If something whizzes, it moves very fast with a humming or hissing sound. A bullet whizzed past his head.
noun In informal language, if you say someone is a whiz at something, you mean that they are very good at it. Ravi's a whiz at programming.
pronoun You use who to ask a question, meaning 'which person'. Who ate the last biscuit?
pronoun You also use who to ask about the identity of someone. Who is the man with the beard?
pronoun You use who to introduce more information about the person you are discussing. The little girl who lives next door started school yesterday.
who's who The who's who of a group or society consists of the most important people in it. He's a well-known trainer, part of the who's who of racing.
pronoun You use whoever to refer to someone when you don't know their name or you're not sure who they are. Jane, or whoever it was that broke the glass, kindly sweep up the pieces.
pronoun You can use whoever for emphasis or to express surprise in questions instead of who. Whoever could it be ringing up so late?
adjective If something is whole, it exists as one thing. It is not divided into separate parts. Swallow the tablet whole. Can we move the desk whole, or will we have to take the legs off?
adjective Whole also refers to the entire quantity of something. I didn't see the whole movie. The whole team played well. He ate a whole box of chocolates on his own.

adjective In informal language, you can use whole for emphasis. Since Bob's been so sick he's had a whole new outlook on life. I've got a whole heap of work to do. You mean I have to wait a whole week for the results? She lost 10 whole kilos.
noun The whole of something is all of it. I was in bed sick the whole of the Christmas holidays.

5 on the whole If you say something is the case on the whole, you mean it is true generally or for the most part. Sometimes you use this phrase to express your opinion or your wishes more tentatively. Enzo's results were very good on the whole. On the whole I'd prefer to have the meeting on Tuesday.
adjective Wholemeal flour or bread is made from the whole grain of the wheat. It has not had the husks removed.
adjective Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in large quantities to shopkeepers, who then sell them to the public at higher prices. The wholesale price is $500 a dozen.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is retail.

form.definition: adjective In formal language, wholesale also means on a very large scale. The isolated killings escalated into a wholesale massacre. If the economy doesn't improve, there will be wholesale redundancies.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb wholesale I bought the stove wholesale through my dad. They were slaughtered wholesale.

form.definition: adjective If something is wholesome, it is healthy and good for you. I bought a wholesome lunch of salad rolls and fresh fruit juice. They moved out of the city as they wanted to bring up their kids in more wholesome surroundings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wholesomeness

form.definition: pronoun In formal language, whom is used instead of who when it is the object of a verb or preposition.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is whopping, you mean that it is very big or great. He caught a whopping fish. She told a whopping lie. The house sold for a whopping two million dollars. I had a whopping bruise where the ball hit me.
noun A whore is a prostitute. Sometimes people call a woman a whore if they do not approve of her sexual behaviour.
pronoun You use whose to show or ask about ownership. That's the lady whose car was stolen. Whose umbrella is this? I don't know whose idea it was.
adverb You use why in questions to find out the reason for something. Why did you throw the rock?
conjunction You use why in indirect questions or statements about the reason for something. I wonder why she left the party so early. That was why she came.
interjection Sometimes you say why in surprise or hesitation. Why, thank you!

4 why not (a) You can use why not in making a suggestion to someone about how they should do something. 'I don't know how I'm going to do all this work.' 'Why not ask Dean to help?' (b) You can say why not when someone suggests something to you, to show that you agree with them. 'How about a game of tennis?' 'Why not?'
noun The wick of a candle is the piece of string in the middle which you light to get a flame.

adjective If someone is wicked, they are morally very bad. This is not a word that you commonly use to describe real people. They fell under the spell of the wicked witch. What you are saying is a wicked lie.

adjective If you say that someone is wicked, you usually mean that they are naughty or mischievous. Sometimes he has a wicked look in his eye. She's got a wicked sense of humour. Her boys get up to some wicked tricks.

noun In cricket, a wicket consists of the three stumps which are stuck in the ground and the two small pieces of wood laid over the top of them. There is a wicket at each end of the pitch. The next ball spun in and hit the wicket.
noun The wicket is also the ground between the two wickets. The bowlers are making the most of the fast wicket.
noun The number of wickets is how many of the batting team are out. England were 5 wickets for 120 at the end of the day.
adjective If something solid is wide, it measures a large amount from one side to the other. A similar word is broad. The table's too wide to fit in the space.
adjective If a gap or opening is wide, there is a large amount of empty space. The doorways are very wide in these old houses.
adjective You use wide to describe how much something measures from one side to the other. At this point in its course the river is only a few metres wide.

adverb If you open something wide, you open it a long way, so that there is a big gap. The baby bird opened its mouth wide. Open the window wide to let in the breeze. She flung the curtains wide to reveal the magnificent view.
adverb If something that you are aiming goes wide, it goes off course. It does not hit the target. He was trying for the bullseye, but all three arrows went wide.

6 wide of the mark If something that you say or guess is wide of the mark, it is not accurate or appropriate. Her comments were rather wide of the mark, as she hadn't kept up with the latest developments. I thought he was about 40, but it turned out I was a long way wide of the mark.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb widen The cracks in the plaster are widening. The council is widening the road.noun width The rug is 215 cm in width. The stick was about the width of my finger.

form.definition: adjective If something is widespread, it exists over a large area or to a large extent. There has been widespread rainfall in the past 24 hours. The decision caused widespread resentment.
noun A widow is a woman whose husband is dead and who has not remarried.
noun A widower is a man whose wife is dead and who has not remarried.
noun A man's wife is the woman he is married to.
noun A wig is a piece of artificial hair worn on the head. The chemotherapy made her hair fall out, so she had to wear a wig. Is that his real hair or is it a wig?
noun In informal language, a wiggle is a small movement to one side, away from a straight line. The path takes a wiggle around the tree here.

verb In informal language, if you say something wiggles, you mean that it moves a small amount from side to side. The handle isn't fixed on properlyit wiggles. You have to wiggle the key in the lock before you can turn it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wiggly She drew a wiggly line across the page. The coffee table is all wiggly.noun wildness The wildness of the storm gradually abated.

form.definition: adjective If an animal or plant is wild, it lives or grows in its natural state. It is not domesticated or cultivated. There are wild camels in some parts of Australia. On our walk we picked bunches of wild flowers.
adjective If something is wild, it is uncontrolled and possibly violent. There are wild storms here in the summer. He has fits of wild rage. They launched themselves into a wild dance.
adverb If someone or something lives or grows wild, they are natural or uncontrolled. During the holidays the children run wild. These fruits grow wild.
the wild The wild is the natural state in which animals or plants live or grow. When the koala had recovered, they released it back into the wild.

wild about In informal language, if you say you're wild about something, you mean that you are very keen on it. You like or enjoy it very much. Matt's wild about surfinghe spends all his time down at the beach.
wild guess A wild guess is a guess that will probably be wrong because you really don't know anything about the subject. 'What's the capital of Chile?' 'No idea, I'll make a wild guessLima?'
wilds The wilds are rough or desert land which is far from cities and even farms.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb wildly He lashed out wildly.

form.definition: noun Wilderness is land in a natural state. We love to go camping in the wilderness.
noun A wilderness is a patch of land that is uncultivated and overgrown. We allowed part of our garden to grow into a wilderness.
noun A wild flower is the flower of a wild plant rather than a cultivated one.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is wildflower.

form.definition: noun Wildlife refers to animals that live in the wild. The fires destroyed wildlife and vegetation in a large area.
adjective If someone is wilful, they are stubborn and always want their own way. Lizzie is a wilful childshe needs to learn to share. There was no overcoming his wilful determination to go ahead.
adjective A wilful act is something bad which is done deliberately. They smashed the shop windows in an incident of wilful vandalism.

verb Will used with another verb shows that someone intends to do something or that something is going to happen in the future. John will leave tomorrow on the early train. The concert will go ahead as planned.
verb Will used with another verb can also indicate willingness to do something. He said he will gladly help if you need him.
verb Will used with another verb can show that something happens often or habitually. She will play by herself for hours.
noun Will is the power of choosing and doing something. Hugo's very sick but he hasn't lost the will to live.
5 noun Will also means what you want. They made her captain of the team against her will.
noun Your will is a legal document in which you state what is to happen to your money and property after you die.

adjective If you are willing to do something, you agree to do it. You do not mind doing it. The bank is willing to lend us the money. I hope Hazel's willing to give me a lift. I'd like to start again, if you're willing. Supatra's always a willing worker.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb willingly She very willingly gave me a lift.

form.definition: noun Your willpower is the strength of your determination. Michael lacks the willpower to study every day.
verb If a plant wilts, it begins to droop because it has lost too much moisture. The flowers are wilting in the hot sun.
verb If you wilt, you begin to lose energy. After three hours I was wilting, but Karen was still going strong.
adjective A wily person lives by cunning or trickery. The police will never catch that wily gang of thieves.

dictionary.entry: wimp /\times,0\wmp/ noun In informal language, a wimp is a coward. Don't be such a wimpgo and complain.

form.definition: verb If you win a match, a competition or an argument, you are successful. You beat the others. Sandra won the 800 metres. Which team do you think will win? He seems to have won the fight against cancer. In these messy divorces, nobody really wins. OK, you win, I'll do it.

verb If you win something, you gain it, especially in a competition. I won second prize in the draw. Merle won first place in the violin section. You could win a trip to Europe. He soon won their respect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See winning.noun win Solveig had a big win in the lottery.noun winner The winner of this round goes through to the final.

form.definition: verb When you wince, the muscles in your face tighten as they do when you feel a sudden pain. Whenever I think of going to the dentist, I wince. I winced with embarrassment at the memory. I accidentally touched his injured arm and he winced.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wince

form.definition: noun Wind is air moving across the land or sea. There's a light wind blowing. Strong winds are forecast for tomorrow. I love to feel the wind in my hair.
noun Your wind is your ability to breathe easily. I had to stop for a while to catch my wind. I'm a bit short of wind these days.
verb If you are winded, you lose your breath and take a while to recover it. The blow to Julio's stomach winded him. By the time we got to the top of the hill I was winded.
noun Wind is also air in the stomach or bowel which causes flatulence. I patted the baby gently on the back to bring up the wind. They say that eating beans gives you wind.
verb If a road or river winds, it has a lot of bends in it. The road winds down the hill to the town.

verb If you wind something, you wrap it or twist it around another object, usually several times. A nurse wound a bandage around his leg. The yarn is wound onto reels. You have to wind the tape over this roller and under that one.
verb If you wind something, you make it move by turning a knob or handle. My watch stopped because I had forgotten to wind it. If the paper jams in the photocopier, use this knob to wind it out.

wind down If something winds down, it becomes gradually less active. The party was beginning to wind down by the time we arrived. They're winding down the export sales department and concentrating on the domestic market.

wind up (a) If you wind up something that is operated by clockwork, you make it go by turning a knob or key. This old clock has to be wound up once a week. He wound up the monkey and watched it walk across the floor.
(b) If you wind up something such as a meeting or activity, you bring it to an end. You finish it. He wound up his lecture with a discussion of the conclusions to be drawn.
(c) In informal language, if you say someone winds someone else up, you mean that they deliberately try to make them angry. Don't take any noticeshe's only winding you up.
noun A window is an opening, usually fitted with glass, which lets in light and air to a room or vehicle.

dictionary.entry: window shopping`wInd@U ;SOpIN noun If you go window shopping, you look at things in shop windows but you do not buy them.

form.definition: noun A windowsill is a ledge along the bottom of a window, on the inside or the outside of a building.
noun Your windpipe is the tube which carries air from your throat to your lungs.
noun A windscreen is the window at the front of a car or truck. A magpie crashed into our windscreen and broke it.
verb If you windsurf, you move over water on a long narrow board with a sail attached to it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun windsurfer noun windsurfing

form.definition: adjective If the weather is windy, a strong wind is blowing. It's very windy out today.
adjective If a road is windy, it has a lot of bends in it.
noun Wine is an alcoholic drink usually made from grapes. Australian wines are excellent and they're exported all over the world.
noun The wings of a bird or insect are the parts that it moves in order to fly.
noun The wings of a plane are the flat parts that stick out on each side.
noun A wing of a building is a part which is joined to the main part. The hospital has a special wing for long-stay patients.
noun A wing within a political party is a group of people who have similar views and aims. The right wing to the Labor Party and the left wing of the Liberal Party are often not so far apart.
noun In soccer, hockey and football, if someone plays on the wing, they play on one of the sides of the forward line.
verb If you wink, you shut one eye and then open it again, usually as a sign to someone. He winked at me to show that he was joking.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wink I'll give you a wink when we pass the bloke I mean.

form.definition: adjective Someone or something is described as winning if they win a match, a competition or an argument. Who holds the winning ticket? The winning stories will be published in the newspaper. Everyone wants to be on the winning side.

adjective If someone, especially a child, is winning, they are appealing in their manner. They make you fond of them. Nick's a toddler now, and he's very winning. She has a winning smile. Be wary of his winning ways.

noun Winter is the coldest season of the year. It comes after autumn and before spring. In Australia the months of June, July and August make up winter. It's nearly winter. I started a new job last winter. I've been in Australia three years this winter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective winter ...winter weather. ...winter clothes.adjective wintry The weather has been really wintry this week.

form.definition: verb If you wipe something, you clean or dry it by rubbing its surface, usually with something such as a cloth. Wipe the dish out before you use itit's got very dusty. He wiped his glasses on his sleeve. I have to keep reminding her to wipe her nose. Jim, please wipe the blackboard.

verb If you wipe something, or wipe it off or away, you remove it from a surface by rubbing something over it. Wipe the dust with this cloth. He wiped the sweat from his brow. I wiped off the marks with a sponge. She comforted the child and wiped away his tears.

wipe out In informal language, if you say someone wipes something out, you mean they destroy it completely. They make it cease to exist. This disease threatens to wipe out the rabbit population. We must wipe out corruption in the police service.
noun Wire is a long, thin piece of metal. We need some wire to mend the fence. The live wire in an electrical cord is brown and the neutral wire is blue.
verb If you wire something, you connect electrical wires so that electricity can pass through it. Max doesn't even know how to wire a plug. Have you got your new hi-fi wired up yet?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wiring The faulty wiring in the old building needs to be replaced.

dictionary.entry: wiry`wa:I@ri:wirierwiriest adjective If someone is wiry, they are thin but fit and strong. The farmer was a wiry old man.

form.definition: noun Your wisdom teeth are the teeth right at the back of your mouth, one on each side of each jaw, that do not come through until you are in your late teens or older. She had to have one of her wisdom teeth removed.

adjective If you are wise, you have a good understanding of life. You are able to use your experience and knowledge to make good decisions. I learned a lot from my wise old teacher. I consulted Marion because she's always very wise about what to do.

adjective If a decision or action is wise, it is sensible. She made the wise choice to stay on at school. You'd be wise to take an umbrella with you. It's wise to keep a spare globe handy. It's not wise to leave it too late.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wisdom Wisdom doesn't always come with age.adverb wisely She wisely decided to turn back.

form.definition: noun A wish is a desire for something. Have you ever had a wish to travel? She felt a growing wish to change her life. I have no wish to continue this discussion. They acted against my express wishes.
noun If you make a wish, you secretly express a desire for something that you hope will come true through magic. Blow out the candles and make a wish. The fairy offered to grant him three wishes.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you wish to do something, you mean that you want to do it. I wish to speak to the manager. We can stay or go, whichever you wish. Feel free to browse for as long as you wish.

verb If you wish someone something, you hope that they will experience it. I wish them all the luck in the world. We all wish you the very best of success in your new job. I wouldn't wish cancer on my worst enemy.

verb If you wish someone goodbye, you say goodbye to them. If you wish someone good luck, you say 'Good luck' or something similar to them. We had a small party to wish them a good trip. She didn't even wish me a happy birthday, let alone give me a present.

best wishes Best wishes is a friendly greeting. It is informal but not particularly intimate. Don't forget to give your mother my best wishes. Dear Marge, Here are the papers that you asked for. Best wishes, Sue.

adjective In informal language, if you say someone or something is wishy-washy, you mean that they are bland or vague. Carol's nice enough, but she infuriates me the way she's so wishy-washy. They came up with a wishy-washy compromise that didn't satisfy either side.
noun Wit is the ability to be clever and amusing with words. She was noted for her savage wit.
noun Wit is also good-humoured perceptiveness. The story is told with wit and insight.
at your wit's end If you are at your wit's end, you are frustrated by a problem and don't know what to do about it. The baby had been screaming for hours and she was at her wit's end.
keep your wits about you If you keep your wits about you, you remain alert and cautious. He'd been in dangerous situations where he had to keep his wits about him.

scare the wits out of you If something scares the wits out of you, it frightens you a lot. You scared the wits out of me when you screamed so loudly. The thought of speaking in public scares the wits out of me.
wits Your wits are your ability to think quickly and clearly. I had to rely on my wits to answer the awkward questions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective witty (wittier, wittiest) ...a witty person. ...a witty remark.

form.definition: noun A witch is a woman who is believed to have magic powers and to use them mostly for evil purposes. It was a story about a wicked witch who turned children into stone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun witchcraft

form.definition: preposition If you are with someone, you are together. I'm going to the party with Paul. I live with my sister.
preposition With also means 'in the care of'. Can I leave my suitcase with you?
preposition With can refer to what you use to do something. The stones are joined with mortar. She swept the floor with a broom.
preposition You can use with to point out someone's characteristics. Is he the man with the beard? ...the boy with the sick mother.
preposition You can use with to show how someone does something. Berndt looked at Julio with fear.
preposition With can show sameness of time or direction. She gets up with the sun. The boat drifted with the current.
preposition In informal language, if you say you're with someone, you mean you understand what they're trying to say or you agree with it. Are you with me so far?

verb In rather formal language, if you say someone withdraws something from somewhere, you mean that they remove it or take it away. Sandy withdrew $500 from her cheque account. The government withdrew funding from the controversial project. The troops have been withdrawn.
verb In formal language, if you say someone withdraws a remark, you mean that they take it back. They apologise for it. The minister last night withdrew her comments about the premier.
verb In formal language, if you say someone withdraws, you mean that they leave or move away. John withdrew, leaving the women to talk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun withdrawal I made a withdrawal of $200.noun withdrawal

dictionary.entry: withholdwID`h@Uld, wIT-withholdswithheld, withholding) verb If you withhold something, you don't give it. You keep it back. The witness withheld important information from the court. He continued to withhold his consent.

form.definition: preposition Within is a formal word meaning inside. There is a secret compartment within the desk. We decided to venture within the cave.

preposition Within is used to emphasise that something doesn't go or extend outside a particular area. Within the wilderness we travelled by jeep. The teacher asked us to keep our answers within the blank spaces.

preposition Within is also used to show that something happens among a particular group. They decided to keep the news within the family. These events were well known within government circles. There is considerable variation within the sample.

preposition If something happens within a certain length of time, it happens before that time is over. I must hand in my assignment within two weeks. She was dismissed within the probation period. I've been sick three times within two months.
adverb Within is a formal word meaning inside. Often it refers to someone's mind or spirit. She felt a great peace within.

within reason If you say someone may do anything within reason, you mean that they may do more or less anything, but not something completely crazy or ridiculous. You can paint your bedroom any colour you like, within reasonI draw the line at black.
preposition If you are without something, you do not have it. I left the house without my umbrella.
preposition Without can also mean 'free from'. They are without money worries now that they've paid off the house.
adverb If you go without, you lack whatever thing is being referred to. The girls ate all the ice-cream, so Martin went without.
noun A witness is someone who sees something happen. I have three witnesses to back up my version of how the accident happened.
noun In a law court, a witness is someone who gives evidence about matters relating to the case. She was called as a witness for the defence.
noun A witness is also someone who signs a legal document to confirm that the other person signing it is who they claim to be. I asked my neighbour to be a witness for the rental lease.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb witness Did you witness the crime? Will you witness my signature?

form.definition: noun A wizard is a man who is believed to have magic powers.
noun In informal language, if you say someone is a wizard at something, you mean that they are very good at it. Celia's a wizard at renovation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wizardry

form.definition: verb If something wobbles, it moves from side to side in an unsteady manner. The front wheel of the cart was wobbling as if it was about to fall off. The pile of books wobbled when I brushed against the table. The kids love making their jellies wobble.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wobbly (wobblier, wobbliest) One of my teeth is wobbly. I put a book under the wobbly leg of the table.

form.definition: noun A woe is a serious problem or misfortune. The cancelled flight was only the beginning of their woes. He told me a long story about his domestic woes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See woeful.

form.definition: adjective If someone is woeful, they are sad and miserable. Don't sit there looking so woefulcome and join us. Julie told me a woeful tale about her daughter's problems.
adjective In informal language, if you say that something is woeful, you mean that it is very bad or disappointing. Attendance at the concert was woefulonly about ten people came.
noun In informal language, a wog is an organism which causes a disease. He's been off work for a week with some kind of wog.
noun Wog is an offensive word for a foreigner.
noun A wok is a large pan with a rounded bottom, used in Chinese cooking.
verb Woke is the past tense of wake.
noun A wolf is a wild animal that looks like a big dog. Wolves go around together killing and eating other animals. The wolf is not a native animal of Australia.

dictionary.entry: woman`wUm@nwomen\minion0\/w\minion0\mn\minion0\/ noun A woman is an adult female human being. Who's that woman in the red dress? My mother was a wonderful woman.

form.definition: noun A woman's womb is the place where babies grow before they are born. The formal word for this is uterus.
noun A wombat is an Australian native animal. It has a strong body and short legs.
verb Won is the past tense and past participle of win.
verb If you wonder about something, you think about it with curiosity. You would like to know more about it. I wonder how much they paid for their house.
verb Sometimes you use 'I wonder' or 'I was wondering' to introduce a remark indirectly. I wonder if you'd like to join me for dinner?
verb If you wonder about something, you have doubts about it. I haven't heard from Joe for agesI wonder if he got my letter. I've always trusted her completely, but lately I've been wondering.
verb In formal language, if you say you wonder at something, you mean that you feel surprise or admiration when you think about it. I wonder at his capacity for hard work.
