noun In formal language, wonder is a feeling of surprise or admiration. I stared at him in wonderhow had he got back so quickly? We looked at the old paintings with wonder.
noun A wonder is something or someone which makes you feel surprise or admiration. The rock formation really was a wonder. Thanks for your helpyou've been a real wonder.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is wonderful, you mean that it is very good or enjoyable. We had a wonderful time at the beach. Our dad's a wonderful cook.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb wonderfully

form.definition: noun Wood is the hard material that is found in the trunk and branches of trees, and is used in building and making furniture. The table is made of solid wood. The surface is inlaid with different woods. We ordered a tonne of wood for the stove.
noun A wood is a large number of trees growing together. We went for a walk in the wood.
noun A wood is also a golf club with a wooden head.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wooden She gave me a wooden pencil case.adjective woody These carrots are rather woody. ...a woody smell. ...a woody suburb.

form.definition: noun The woodwork in a house or building consists of all the things that are made of wood, such as the doors and window frames. How long did it take to paint the woodwork? The woodwork is infested with termites.
noun Woodwork is also the craft of making things in wood. Gina is doing a course in woodwork.
noun Wool is the thick soft hair which covers sheep and some other animals. Wool is one of Australia's major exports.
noun Wool is the yarn or fabric made from this. This carpet is pure wool.
noun People often refer to the yarn that they use for knitting as wool, even if it is nylon or cotton.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective woollen I bought a thick woollen jumper.

form.definition: noun A word is a unit of language that has some meaning on its own. You put words together in sentences when you speak or write. He asked us to write a short essay of 300 words. It's hard to put the feeling into words. I couldn't find the word in the dictionary. 'Thankyou' can be written as one word or two.
verb You word a message by choosing the right words to express your meaning. I worded the letter carefully to avoid hurting his feelings. She received a strongly worded rebuke.

noun In fairly formal language, if someone brings or sends word about something, they convey a message. Alex brought us word of the family back home. Mr Higgins is delayed, but he sends word that we should start without him.

noun In various fairly formal phrases, your word means a solemn promise. I give you my word it won't happen again. He kept his word. He was as good as his word. He broke his word. He went back on his word.

eat your words If you say you eat your words, you mean that you take back what you said because you have been proved wrong. He said we'd never manage it, but he was forced to eat his words. Well, I eat my wordsyou've done a really good job there!

give the word If you give the word for something to happen, you give the order or signal for it to begin. The project is ready to start as soon as head office gives us the word. You have only to give the word and I'll be happy to help you move.
7 have a word If you have a word with someone, you speak to them about something. I've been meaning to have a word with you about how things are going. Could we have a word when you've got a minute?
have words If you have words with someone, you argue or quarrel. It was a difficult meetingJulie and Don had words about the budget.
in a word You can use in a word to summarise what you mean and express it briefly. He is arrogant, mean and selfishin a word, a total bastard.

in so many words If you say something in so many words, you say it quite clearly and openly. He accused me in so many words of being a liar. She told the boss in so many words that he should mind his own business when it comes to her private life.

the last word (a) If you have the last word in a discussion or argument, you have the final or decisive say. We can all express our opinions, but it's Daniel who has the last word about which one we buy. She can never let a matter dropshe always has to have the last word.

(b) If you say something is the last word in something, you mean that it has that quality to a very high degree. Her unit is the last word in elegant design. He thinks he's the last word in sophistication. This gadget is the last word in electronic wizardry.

word for word If you repeat or quote something word for word, you use the exact words in which it was originally expressed. This thankyou letter is word for word the same as last year! I can't remember it word for word, but it's something like 'By channels of coolness the echoes are calling'.

noun A word processor is a computer program which allows you to type and format documents. The computer comes complete with a word processor and a spreadsheet. I write all my essays with a word processor.
verb Wore is the past tense of wear.
verb When you work, you do the job which you are paid to do. Maria works two days a week. Sally works in a bank. Romolo works as a machinist.
verb When you work, you put effort into doing something. He's been working hard because he wants to do well in his exams. I really have to work at keeping my weight down.
verb If something such as a machine or an appliance works, it does what it is designed to do. The fridge is old, but it still works. I can't get this photocopier to work.
verb If something such as an idea or plan works, it is successful. Let's see if your suggestion works.
verb If you work something such as a machine or appliance, you operate it. Please show me how to work the video recorder.
verb If you work someone, you make them put effort into something. She's a good teachershe really works the students. The prisoners of war were worked until they collapsed.
noun Your work is your employment. What work do you do? I've been looking for work for three months. I finish work at noon. She's a friend from work.
noun Work is the effort you make to achieve something. All our hard work paid off in the end. It's hard work weeding the garden.
noun In formal language, a work is something made or created. Entrants may submit a maximum of three works for the art competition. I bought a copy of the complete works of Henry Lawson.

make short work of If you make short work of something, you finish or deal with it quickly or easily. We were all hungry so we made short work of the sandwiches. If we get organised we can make short work of cleaning the house. She made short work of his objections to the idea.
the works In informal language, the works means all of the appropriate things. I want a hamburger with the works. They're going to have a church wedding with flowers, bridesmaids, the works.
work back If you work back, you work in your job for extra time at the end of the day. The boss asked me to work back to finish the accounts.
work of art (a) A work of art or an art work is something that is made or created by an artist, such as a painting or a sculpture. The museum displays works of art from around the world.

(b) If you say something that someone has made or done is a work of art, you mean that it is very beautifully or skilfully done. The cake she made for the party was a work of artit was a shame to eat it.
work out (a) If you work out a problem, you solve it by thinking about it. Eventually I worked out how to load the paper. I can't work out what this means.

(b) If a situation works out, it turns out all right. I hope your new job works out well. Everything will work out just fine, you'll see. There was a lot of confusion, but in the end it all worked out.
(c) If you work out, you do physical exercise in order to improve your physical fitness. Ron works out at the gym twice a week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun worker The company has retrenched 200 workers. Lisa is a good worker..

form.definition: noun A workbench is a heavy table or a hard surface that people work on with tools.
noun Workforce refers to all the people in a particular country, area or industry who are employed. Working mothers form an increasing part of Australia's workforce.
noun Your workload is the amount of work that you have to do. The sales department are complaining about their workload. I've got a pretty heavy workload over the next couple of weeks.
noun A workout is a time when you do physical exercise in order to improve your physical fitness. Ron does a vigorous workout at the gym twice a week.

dictionary.entry: workplace`w@:kplEIs noun A workplace is somewhere where people work. ...a course in English for the workplace.

form.definition: noun A workshop is a room or place with tools and machinery for making or repairing things.

noun The world is the planet earth on which we live, and all the countries and places in it. I bought a ticket to fly round the world. I love to travel and see the world. People visit Australia from all over the world. Environmental campaigners want to save the world.

noun A world can be a particular field of interest or activity and the people who are involved in it. He's an important figure in the literary world. I was keen to get out of the business world. The scandal shocked the racing world. We come from different worlds, but we get on.
on top of the world If you are on top of the world, you are feeling extremely happy. Jenna was on top of the world when she heard she'd got the job.

out of this world In informal language, if you say something is out of this world, you mean that it is extraordinarily good. Her singing was out of this world. This cheesecake is absolutely deliciousout of this world!
think the world of If you think the world of someone, you like and admire them very much. My son thinks the world of his teacher.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective world We went on a world tour. He's the world champion. ...a new world record.

form.definition: adjective Worldwide means occurring throughout the world. He's achieved worldwide fame with his latest novel.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb worldwide The novel is being sold worldwide.

form.definition: noun A worm is a small, legless creature which lives in the soil. The worms come to the surface after it rains.
noun You can also call a caterpillar or grub a worm. There was a worm in the apple.
noun If you refer to someone as a worm, you mean that you have no respect for them. He didn't even have the grace to apologise, the miserable worm.
verb If someone worms somewhere, they crawl or wriggle like a worm. I wormed through a hole in the fence. The baby wormed across the carpet. He wormed his way into her affections.

can of worms If you say an issue is a can of worms, you mean that it's very complicated and difficult. It is easier not to get involved with it. I mentioned the question of subsidies, but he warned me to leave that can of worms alone.

worm out of If you worm something out of someone, you manage to get them to tell you what you want to know even though they are reluctant. She just sat there sobbing, but I eventually wormed out of her what the problem was. She wormed the secret out of him by expressing concern.
verb Worn is the past participle of wear.
adjective If something such as a garment or carpet is worn, it is thin or damaged because it has been used so much.
adjective If someone looks worn, they look tired and older than they really are, usually because they are worried or sick.
adjective If something is worn-out, it is damaged from too much use. You should throw away those worn-out shoes. The washer in the tap is worn-out and will have to be replaced.

verb If you worry about something, you feel anxious and concerned about what might happen or go wrong. I worry about her living on her own. Don't worry, everything will be fine. He does have a tendency to worry.

verb If you tell someone not to worry about something, you mean that they shouldn't bother with it. Don't worry about cups and saucersthese mugs are fine. Don't worry about coming to fetch meI'll make my own way there.

If something worries you, it makes you anxious or concerned. His drinking worries me. It worries me that they haven't contacted us. Don't let the delay worry you. None of these difficulties worried him in the slightest.

verb If something worries you, it bothers or disturbs you. The noise of the fan began to worry me. Will it worry you if I use the telephone? Don't worry me nowI'm busy. I try to stop the kids worrying Nellie when she's working.
verb When one animal worries another, it bites it and shakes it. A man stopped the cat worrying the injured bird. The dog had to be put down because it had started worrying sheep.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective worried I'm worried about Rita. He had a worried look. noun worry (worries) They have money worries. I couldn't sleep for worry.adjective worrying There has been a worrying increase in crime.

form.definition: adjective Worse is the comparative form of bad. If something is worse, it is less good than it was before, or less good than something else. My cold is getting worse. The first half of the concert was fairly boring, but the second half was worse.
adverb Worse is the comparative form of badly. I'll try againafter all I can hardly do worse than last time!
none the worse for If you are none the worse for an experience, you are not harmed by it. The walkers were found early the next morning, none the worse for their night in the bush.
worse off If you are worse off, you are poorer or in a less favourable situation. After all our efforts we were worse off than when we started.
worse than useless If you say something is worse than useless, you mean that it is of no use at all. Sam's attempts to get us going again were worse than useless.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb worsen The weather worsened, so we decided to turn back.

form.definition: verb If you worship a god, you show respect and reverence by praying and carrying out ceremonies and rituals. Hindus worship a number of gods. People come from all over the world to worship at this shrine.
verb If you worship someone, they are extremely important to you. You think that they are wonderful. Georgio really worships his daughter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun worship This daily act of worship is an important part of the religion.noun worshipper Thousands of worshippers gathered in the temple.

form.definition: adjective Worst is the superlative form of bad. This is the worst cold I've ever had in my life. Even the worst weather didn't discourage them.
adverb Worst is the superlative form of badly. This detergent performed worst in our tests.

noun If something is the worst, it is worse than everything else. I've seen some violent movies, but this is the worst. She was the worst of the dancers. We're over the worst now. What's the worst that could happen? We'll be an hour late at worst.

if the worst comes to the worst When you say what you will do if the worst comes to the worst, you mean that you have a plan in mind in case things go wrong. If the worst comes to the worst and I'm running late, I'll take a taxi.
adjective If something is worth a certain amount of money, that is its value. Her diamond ring is worth $2000. It's only jade, but it's worth a lot to me because of its sentimental value.

adjective You use worth to say whether something repays the effort you make. If you like history the museum is worth a visit. Is this old coat worth cleaning? It's not worth going so far for a week. It's worth keeping a copy in case the original gets lost.

noun You use worth to talk about the amount of something in terms of the money it costs. He bought $20 worth of chocolate. The vandals did $50 000 worth of damage. Three years worth of work went up in the blaze. She's got 15 years worth of records filed away.

noun In formal language, the worth of something or someone is its value or importance. He was asked to estimate the worth of the vase. The incident proved the worth of his training. It's hard to cling on to your sense of worth when you're unemployed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective worthless It was a worthless fake. Your promises are worthless to me.

form.definition: adjective If something is worthwhile, it repays the effort you make. Her gratitude made all my work worthwhile. It's worthwhile spending some time on revision every week. I wish they could find some more worthwhile activity than playing video games.

dictionary.entry: worthy`w@:Di:worthierworthiest adjective If you are worthy of something, you deserve it. He began his speech by saying he didn't feel worthy of the honour. Charlene was a worthy winner. This is an achievement worthy of recognition.

form.definition: verb Would is used after a clause introduced by if.
verb Would is used to indicate actions that used to happen continually, in the past. When he was little his mother would cut his hair.
verb You can use would to show that you want to do something. John would love to come to the party.
verb You can use would to make questions more polite. Would you like another sandwich? Would you mind turning out the light?
verb If you say that someone would do something, you mean that such behaviour is typical of them. 'Carlos complained again.' 'He would.'
verb Wound is the past tense and past participle of wind (senses 5-9).
noun A wound is an injury to the body. The victim had stab wounds to his chest and neck. The soldier died of his wounds. Wash the wound carefully and cover it with a dressing.
verb If someone is wounded, they are injured, especially in a fight.
verb If someone wounds you, they hurt your feelings. They make you feel upset. John was wounded by my criticism of his work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY wounded adjective She looked wounded when I mentioned her lateness.noun wounded A field hospital was set up to tend the wounded.adjective wounding I found her callousness very wounding.

form.definition: verb Woven is the past participle of weave.
You can use wow when you want to show that you like something very much or you are very impressed by it. Wow! I like your handbag! Wow! Where did you get such a great bargain?

dictionary.entry: wowser`wa:Uz@ noun In informal language, if a person calls someone a wowser, they are criticising them because they do not drink alcohol.

form.definition: verb If you wrap something, you fold paper or some other material around it so as to cover it completely. Jane wrapped the Christmas presents in red paper. The sales assistant offered to wrap my purchases. Dad wrapped the hot water tank with insulation.
verb If you wrap yourself in something, you fold it around you so as to keep warm or covered. She sat on the couch wrapped in a blanket.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wrap She was wearing a woollen wrap.noun wrapper Be sure and put the wrappers from your ice blocks in the bin.noun wrapping I eagerly tore the wrapping off the parcel to find out what was inside.

form.definition: noun A wreath is an arrangement of flowers and leaves woven into a circle. ...a funeral wreath. ...a Christmas wreath. The premier laid a wreath at the memorial.
verb A wreck is an accident in which a vehicle is severely damaged and often people are killed. Only nineteen sailors survived the wreck. There was a terrible train wreck last year.
noun A wreck is a vehicle which has been severely damaged in an accident. Divers have recovered gold coins from the wreck. He buys up car wrecks and strips them for spares.
noun In informal language, if you call someone a wreck, you mean that they are in a bad way physically or mentally. Poor Ernie has been a wreck since his wife left him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb wreck The ship was wrecked on an iceberg. The delay wrecked my holiday plans.verb wreckage They cut her free of the wreckage. Wreckage was strewn across the freeway.

form.definition: verb If you wrestle with someone, you fight them and try to throw them to the ground. He wrestled with his attacker and managed to disarm him.
verb If you wrestle with a problem, you try very hard to solve it or deal with it. I wrestled with the decision for days before accepting the offer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun wrestler He's a professional wrestler.noun wrestling Dad watches the wrestling on TV.

form.definition: noun A wretch is an unfortunate person. The poor wretch lost everything in the earthquake.
noun A wretch is also a person who causes you trouble or annoyance. I'd like to catch the wretch who dented my car!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective wretched They lead a wretched existence. Where is the wretched boy now?

form.definition: verb If you wriggle, you twist and turn your body. The little girl wriggled with delight as I tickled her. The boys wriggled under the fence. She tried to wriggle her feet into the tight boots.
get a wriggle on In informal language, if you tell someone to get a wriggle on, you want them to hurry up. We'd better get a wriggle on or we'll miss the bus.

wriggle out of If someone wriggles out of something, they manage to avoid it, although that isn't fair. Somehow Stefan always wriggles out of doing the washing up. There was enough evidence to prosecute, but she wriggled out on a technicality.

verb If you wring a wet cloth, you twist and squeeze it to get the water out of it. Wring the towels before you hang them up, or else they'll never dry. Wring the mop so that you don't get too much water on the floor.
wringing wet If you say that something is wringing wet, you mean that it is completely soaked. We got caught in the rain and came home wringing wet.

wring your hands If you wring your hands, you twist and turn them together in a very agitated manner because you feel upset and helpless. The child's father sat wringing his hands in the waiting room.
verb A wrinkle in a piece of cloth or paper is a small crease.
noun Wrinkles are the lines that appear on your face as you get older.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb wrinkle Hang your skirt up so it won't wrinkle.adjective wrinkled The old man had a wrinkled face.

form.definition: noun Your wrist is the joint where your hand is attached to your arm.
verb When you write, you record words or numbers on paper. He wrote the address on the envelope. I can speak a bit of Korean, but I can't write it.

verb When you write something such as a letter, you compose it using your own words. I wrote Tony a postcard from Perth. I've got to write an essay about tourism. He wrote his first novel when he was only 22.
verb If you write to someone, you send them a letter. Have a good trip and don't forget to write! I wrote to the council to complain. Susanne writes that all the family are well.

write off (a) If you write something off, you don't bother with it any more. The credit company agreed to write off the debt. Rob's father wrote him off when he gave up his studies. The doctors had written her off, but she made a full recovery.
(b) If you write off a car in a smash, you damage it so badly that it is not worth repairing.
write up If you write something up, you record it in writing. June decided to write up her experience. I want to write up my notes while the lecture's still fresh in my mind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See write-off.noun writer He's a well-known writer. She's a sports writer on a local paper.noun writing Please apply in writing. Her writing's very hard to read.adjective written Please submit a written request.

form.definition: noun A write-off is a car that has been so badly damaged in a smash that it is not worth repairing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See write.

form.definition: adjective If something is wrong, it is morally bad. It's wrong to tell lies. He refused to admit that he had done anything wrong.
adjective If something is wrong, it is not correct. I'm afraid that's the wrong answerit's actually 23. Is my watch wrong, or is the train late?
adjective If you are wrong, you are mistaken. I was wrong about the dateit's actually next Tuesday. Alright, I admit I was wronghe's done a very good job.
adjective If something is the wrong thing, it is not the proper or appropriate one. I caught the wrong bus and ended up miles away. Those are the wrong shoes to wear with that suit.
noun In formal language, a wrong is something unjust or unfair. She wants to be a lawyer to right some of the wrongs she sees. He felt that he had been done a wrong.

get on the wrong side of If you get on the wrong side of someone, you do something which annoys them and makes them dislike you. You don't want to get on the wrong side of Elaineshe can be very spiteful.
in the wrong If someone is in the wrong, they are at fault or to blame. It's not for you to apologise when he's in the wrong.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb wrong She felt that she had been wronged by their treatment of her.adjective wrongful He threatened to take legal action for wrongful arrest.

form.definition: verb Wrote is the past tense of write.
verb Wrung is the past tense and past participle of wring.

dictionary.entry: wusswUs noun In informal language, a wuss is someone who is not very capable or competent.[fa[xp
